articles.headline: China’s Financial Industry Recruits Abroad
articles.snippet: Chinese institutions are taking advantage of the downturn and focusing on the newly unemployed to upgrade their own staffs.
articles.abstract: Chinese institutions are taking advantage of the downturn and focusing on the newly unemployed to upgrade their own staffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK  Mary Yu pitches hard to the recruiter sitting in front of her. “I’ve got experience in risk management,” she explains, naming the bank where she works and watching anxiously as the recruiter scribbles on her résumé.

articles.headline: Iraq Unsettled by Political Power Plays
articles.snippet: Different factions within the Iraqi government — and some outside it — are struggling to gain ground as U.S. influence wanes.
articles.abstract: Different factions within the Iraqi government — and some outside it — are struggling to gain ground as U.S. influence wanes.
articles.lead_paragraph: With provincial elections scheduled for the end of January, Iraq appears to be plagued by political troubles that seem closer to Shakespearean drama than to nascent democracy.

articles.headline: French Unions Losing Influence in Downturn
articles.snippet: Unions in France have been tamed by Nicolas Sarkozy, the president, and the economic crisis.
articles.abstract: Unions in France have been tamed by Nicolas Sarkozy, the president, and the economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOCHAUX, France  When the financial crisis in the United States washed up on Europe’s shores and pushed the economy into recession, the workers at the Peugeot car plant in this village in eastern France were afraid  and angry.

articles.headline: Qualifying Tests for Chinese Financial Workers
articles.snippet: In response to the global financial crisis, China has increased the number of qualification tests for workers in the financial sector.
articles.abstract: In response to the global financial crisis, China has increased the number of qualification tests for workers in the financial sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Li Wuchen is 33 years old and has worked as a stock broker for three years, but he looked as nervous as a high school student facing the SAT as he stood outside a university building on a recent Saturday morning and studied a government-issued manual one last time.

articles.headline: Solar Meets Polar as Winter Curbs Clean Energy
articles.snippet: Many alternative energy sources like wind turbines and solar panels experience problems in cold weather.
articles.abstract: Many alternative energy sources like wind turbines and solar panels experience problems in cold weather.
articles.lead_paragraph: Old Man Winter, it turns out, is no friend of renewable energy.

articles.headline: Chinese Savings Helped Inflate American Bubble
articles.snippet: China, some economists say, lulled U.S. consumers and leaders into complacency about their spendthrift ways.
articles.abstract: China, some economists say, lulled U.S. consumers and leaders into complacency about their spendthrift ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Usually it’s the rich country lending to the poor. This time, it’s the poor country lending to the rich.”

articles.headline: Fiscal Chaos Aside, Start-Ups Bloom in Argentina
articles.snippet: Argentine entrepreneurs have created a nascent start-up ecosystem with local venture capital funds and angel investors.
articles.abstract: Argentine entrepreneurs have created a nascent start-up ecosystem with local venture capital funds and angel investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENDOZA, Argentina  Even in the best of times, Felix Racca faced a formidable task  trying to build a new class of entrepreneurs in a country known for cozy cronyism and political melodrama. And now, the Argentine angel investor is trying to do it in the middle of a global storm that has sucked billions of investor dollars out of emerging markets.

articles.headline: Pakistan Moves Troops Amid Tension With India
articles.snippet: Two officials said troops were headed to the Indian border, but there was little to indicate a major redeployment.
articles.abstract: Two officials said troops were headed to the Indian border, but there was little to indicate a major redeployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan has begun moving some troops away from its western border with Afghanistan and has stopped soldiers from going on leave amid rising tensions with India, Pakistani officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Salman Masood
